text: let's hear it for the a fer mentioned
Lucy Hawking
that's not my experiment that went wrong
it wasn't meant to be the microphone oh
okay I'll leave it like that now so my
flight from Japan landed in Los Angeles
and I went through the airport and I
collect my bags and I go outside and I
put my suitcase down and I sit on it and
I light a cigarette and I think what the
hell am I doing here
I mean I've just told an immigration
agent that I've come here to see my dad
who's in Pasadena at Caltech doing a
sabbatical but what I didn't say is that
actually I live 10 minutes away from my
dad in the university city of Cambridge
Waihee Stephen Hawking is the professor
of mathematics and I go round to see him
so often that lately he started begging
me to go and get a life of my own so the
idea that I've actually gone from London
to Tokyo to Los Angeles to Pasadena just
to have a cup of tea with him is clearly
absurd but something has drawn me here
something has drawn me to California and
I don't know what it is outside the
airport the sunshine seems kind of
blindingly bright I've been in Japan for
a week and I've been on a promotional
tour and my Japanese hosts work Highness
and politeness and charm itself but even
that couldn't take away a kind of
dislocation which comes from spending a
week in back-to-back interviews
answering questions about myself about
the book about my family about my father
all the while presided over by a huge
blow-up photograph of myself by the end
of the week I've become such a
narcissist
I'm starting to think I'd quite like to
meet myself I sound quite nice but that
that passes quite quickly so I make my
way to Pasadena where my dad is staying
in a Caltech campus house and I go
through the door and it's like I have
walked through a doorway into my own
past I mean it's no disrespect to Cal
Tech's interior decorating policy but it
clearly hasn't changed since 1974 when
my family moved into another Cal Tech
campus house but then I was three and my
dad was already in a wheelchair but he
could speak with his own voice and he
could get around by himself he was at
Cal Tech where he was coming to the
realization that when stars implode to
form black holes and then the hole
evaporates in Hawking radiation the
information very probably gets lost and
this is in violation of the laws of
quantum mechanics at least in their
usual form he wrote his famous
information loss paper this year and he
assigned to Dom page the task of
computing in detail what kind of
particles come out of a black hole in
Hawking radiation and how many of which
type his lifelong friend and colleague
Kip Thorne was trying to figure out what
kind of objects in the universe would
admit gravitational waves that will be
strong enough for us to detect and
others in his group were trying to
figure out what hot disks of gas around
a black hole would look like when we saw
them from a distant telescope on earth
at the end of a hard day's theoretical
graft my dad would take me and my mom
and my brother down to the Baskin
Robbins 31 flavor ice cream parlor at
the end of the road 31 flavors my
brother and I think we have arrived in
paradise we learn to swim we go surfing
we actually invent our own new sport
which involves sneaking into the Caltech
offices when the scientists aren't
looking to write our own bogus equations
on the blackboards
we pick avocados off the tree in our
back garden in Pasadena and we smear
ourselves in green paste so we can run
around going look mummy we're monsters
I especially agreed with that actually
and everything to my three-year-old eyes
looks infinite the fun the sunshine the
happiness the Pacific Ocean but I'm
brought back to the reality of 2008 with
a jolt my dad isn't well and he's gone
to the hospital with two of his carers
by now he's been living with ALS for
over 40 years and he needs 24-hour care
and he now speaks with a computer
synthesized voice I want to go and see
him in the hospital but I can't he's
surrounded by doctors and nurses and
carers and I can't really get close to
him so I just have to wait with the rest
of the care team and his technical
assistant and so we sit there and we
wait and we talk in that kind of weird
way that people do when they're very
very anxious but they don't actually
want to show it and so they tell me
about their journey and that was fun
they were sitting in the row behind the
film star selma hayek on the plane and
they all fell in love with her and then
they arrived and they found that three
of their 25 suitcases had been tampered
with and some of our vital medical
equipment is missing and I just think oh
my god we are so far from home my dad's
in hospital I can't be with him in the
hospital but I can't really be with him
anywhere because wherever he is he needs
all these people and someone's nicked
our stuff and I'm not with my friends
and I'm not with my family but I'm here
with this very diverse group of people
who work for my dad who range from an
A&E nurse from Dublin Ireland to a man
from the Hunan Province of China to a
Cambridge graduate in engineering and it
all just seems so strange so kind of
heartbreakingly unimaginably bizarre and
I try and sort of think back to a time
when we actually had a normal life and
all I can think of is when I was three
and I was obsessed by fairy stories
especially the ones where you were
granted wishes and you were given a wish
and your wish could come true because I
had a wish I wanted to come true I
wanted to have a wish that would make my
dad be able to walk and you see I've
never actually seen him be able to walk
except for the once I did once see him
walk but it wasn't actually him it was a
play that I went to about my parents in
the 60s and an actor came out onto the
stage and he looked just like my dad
and he could walk and he could talk and
then an actress came out and she looked
just like my mom and they were so young
and so happy and so in love and I just
wanted to crawl up onto the stage and be
with them but then suddenly my dad is
back he's checked himself out of
hospital it was boring apparently and
now he wants to go out for dinner so
very quickly we booked a table for eight
we paint her nails we put on our dresses
and we go to Jennifer Lopez's restaurant
for dinner and salsa dancing and we have
a great night out my dad is surrounded
by beautiful young ladies who want to
talk physics to him the rest of us do
some dancing and we make some new
friends and like every time when we go
out on mass on Entourage people drive
themselves nuts trying to work out the
different links between us all and like
every time they get it completely wrong
I mean younger carers are often thought
to be my dad's kids older ones his
parents I'm quite often mistaken for his
secretary and on one occasion the mother
of his Technical Assistant which was a
bit of a blow because he's a lovely guy
but he's 25 as I said we have a great
night out and it grinds to an end around
2:00 a.m. when even the most Hardy
Nightbird professor of mathematics has
to admit it is now time to give up and
go home and get some rest now the next
day is Sunday and we've got all our
Californian friends are coming around
for a barbecue and this is
a crazy idea because we are British we
know nothing about barbecues I decide to
make some guacamole
it'll be a bit experimental I say
because I've never made it before but
how hard can it be a look of panic
crosses my dad's face and it occurs to
me that the last time I cooked a lunch
party for him I set fire to a plastic
box of muesli and we had to evacuate his
house due to the clouds of toxic black
smoke relax I say it'll be fine what
could go wrong I press a few buttons on
the mixer and WHAM the whole thing
explodes it is the avocado big bang in
our kitchen green matter is ejected at
speed from the mixer it goes everywhere
it covers my chest my hair it flies in a
fabulous arc across the kitchen
cupboards hitting one two three people
standing by and ending up on my dad
there is a moment of shocked silence so
we all just stand there and I look up to
the heavens for solace and that's when I
realize that the guacamole has hit the
ceiling too and I start to laugh and
that's when we realized the other thing
that when Sam the technical assistant
went out into the garden to light the
barbecue a spark jumped from the coals
and now the flower bed is on fire and
somehow somehow in the ensuing chaos I
get it
I realize what brought me back to
Pasadena I went back there I wanted to
go back there because I was kind of
chasing my own memories I was looking
for a kind of idealized picture of a
golden age in our family life a time of
simplicity of normality a time before
illness and before Fame and a time when
we traveled through life lightly without
seven extra people and 25 suitcases and
so much has happened since then we've
had so many challenges
and so many changes we've had so much
that was unexpected extraordinary or
unusual but it strikes me as I stand
there once more in Pasadena
once more covered in avocado that we've
come through it and that yes this is an
unusual way to live your life but it's
okay it really is okay and you see last
summer an air hostess said to me as we
were getting off a plane it was me my
dad his care team my 9 year old son and
she said to me I think you are an
amazing family and at the time it was
kind of weird that she said that but
thinking back I realized she was right
that we are an amazing family and I feel
so proud of us both of my real family
and of this kind of different shaped
family that we fashioned out of the
people who work and work for and support
my dad and who I've also spent so much
time with and had so many experiences
with and here we are at Caltech where
some of the greatest discoveries in
science have been made at Caltech and
many of them in physics and physics can
explain to you what holds planets
together what holds solar systems
together what holds whole galaxies
together but it can't tell you what
holds people together and that's what
we've got thank you for listening
you
